body:
directly indexing on floats is a very odd, unreliable thing to do.

in 0.17.0 (releasing shortly), you may have better experience doing this:

```
In [31]: df4.reindex([1.13,1.14,1.15],tolerance=0.005,method='nearest')
Out[31]: 
      values
1.13    1.13
1.14    1.14
1.15    1.15
```

more typically you would do this

```
In [36]: df4[(df4.index>=1.13)&(df4.index<=1.15)]
Out[36]: 
      values
1.13    1.13
1.14    1.14
```

Thanks Jeff

That’s the fastest support response I think I’ve ever seen…

I understand about indexing on floats – that is just to make the concat step work. In my actual code I later replace the index with ints anyway.

The problem is that I want to be able to look up a value in one column using the value in an interpolated column (not the index).

Brian

From: Jeff Reback [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: 09 September 2015 17:17
To: pydata/pandas pandas@noreply.github.com
Cc: Davison, Brian B.Davison@napier.ac.uk
Subject: Re: [pandas] BUG: Invisible rounding error in the results of Dataframe.interpolate() (#11035)

see herehttp://pandas-docs.github.io/pandas-docs-travis/whatsnew.html#other-enhancements down a bit

if you need _exact_ numbers, then you should make these integers (e.g. multiply by factor, then round, and cast to an int). otherwise you will have issues.

maybe a small example if what you are ultiemately doing would help.

Hi Jeff

I’ll use that approach – no need for an example.

Thanks for the advice
Brian

From: Jeff Reback [mailto:notifications@github.com]
Sent: 09 September 2015 17:25
To: pydata/pandas pandas@noreply.github.com
Cc: Davison, Brian B.Davison@napier.ac.uk
Subject: Re: [pandas] BUG: Invisible rounding error in the results of Dataframe.interpolate() (#11035)

if you need exact numbers, then you should make these integers (e.g. multiply by factor, then round, and cast to an int). otherwise you will have issues.

maybe a small example if what you are ultiemately doing would help.
